author: irishmirror
title: Liverpool fans plan banner tribute to Plymouth supporter's son who died during FA Cup tie
text:
Sport Liverpool fans plan banner tribute to Plymouth supporter's son who died during FA Cup tie Argyle fan Kevin May learned his son was dying as his side were playing Liverpool at Anfield on Sunday Share Kevin May's son Daniel, right, died on Sunday (Photo: SWNS.com) Share Get   Thank you for subscribing!   
Fans of Liverpool are planning to pay tribute to a Plymouth supporter's son who died during Sunday's FA Cup stalemate at Anfield. 
Argyle fan Kevin May's son, Daniel, devastatingly passed away in the Surrey hospital he was being treated in the day after he suffered a cardiac arrest. 
Kevin was at Anfield when he heard the news that his son was about to die and was comforted by a police officer and a Liverpool employee. 
He later wrote a message of thanks on Liverpool's Facebook page for the way he was treated at the stadium, which has since gone viral. 
Now Reds season ticket holder Anthony Grice has set up a fundraising page, “LFC banner in memory of Daniel May”, which has already raised £720 - five times more than the page's original £150 target. Kevin was in the away section at Anfield when he learned his son was about to die (Photo: Michael Steele/Getty Images) 
Reds fans are planning to display a banner in memory of Daniel when Liverpool travel to Plymouth for the FA Cup third-round replay next week. 
In an emotional post on the official Liverpool FC Facebook page earlier this week, Kevin said he was distraught when he discovered Daniel, 25, was “flat lining and was about to die” in hospital – but a police officer in the ground came to his aid. 
When his son passed away, he said he was supported by the officer and an Anfield employee, who put their arms around him to comfort him. 
Mr May said he still felt alone – but hearing Liverpool FC supporters singing You’ll Never Walk Alone helped to lift his spirits. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Share this video Watch Next 
Father-of-two Mr Grice, 37, said: “I take my son to the match, he’s eight and he doesn’t even like football but it’s a dad and lad thing. 
“As a parent it was hard to read the story. I was in floods of tears and couldn’t hold myself together. I know a lot of people who read it have been in pieces. 
“I mentioned it on Twitter and everyone’s said it’s a fantastic idea and that they wanted to help. 
“Some people have even said they want to give me their donations in cash at the next match.” Liverpool and Plymouth drew 0-0 on Sunday (Photo: Getty) 
The banner is being produced by a shop on Smithdown Road and will include the words “RIP Daniel May”, You’ll Never Walk Alone and the image of a Liver Bird. 
It will be held aloft at Liverpool FC’s FA Cup third-round replay against Plymouth Argyle at Home Park next Wednesday, January 18. 
Mr Grice said the banner would cost just over £100 – and the rest of the money will be donated to Royal Surrey County hospital, where Daniel passed away. Liverpool plan to take a banner down to Plymouth for the away leg in remembrance of Kevin's son Daniel (Photo: Michael Steele/Getty Images) 
On the fundraising page he wrote: “We are creating a banner for supporters to take to Plymouth away next week in Memory of Daniel May who passed away. 
“Banner to be held aloft by LFC fans during YNWA and during a minute of applause in the 25th minute of the game.” 
Mr Grice added: “Hopefully this is a classy little touch and something we can do for the family as Liverpool supporters.” 
In his Facebook post, Mr May said the men who helped him were “an absolute credit to Liverpool FC” and he wanted to thank them for the “care and the kind words” at his time of need.
